info.game_comments:
Doug Dorst game 1.
Portions of the Double Jeopardy! round used as background in the film Georgia Rule.

(1, 1).clue: The 2 things the U.S. has "for all" in the Pledge of Allegiance

(2, 1).clue: Like Manilow's "Lola",  Evelyn Nesbitt was one of these theater females; in 1906, her rich, crazy husband shot her ex-lover

(4, 1).clue: The Jaffa Gate is the western entrance to this city's Old City

(5, 1).clue: The smallest bird in the world is the bee type of this from Cuba

(1, 2).clue: Decades before Lincoln, Daniel Webster spoke of government "made for", "made by" & "answerable to" them

(2, 2).clue: In 2005, 1,000 champagne corks popped as a Brazilian equestrian married Athina of this clan

(3, 2).clue: "Timeless American Style" was the hallmark of this fashion designer born in the Indiana heartland

(4, 2).clue: Savior's Gate is the way into this fortress complex for leaders like Vladimir Putin

(5, 2).clue: With molecules used as beads, IBM researches created the world's smallest one of these counting devices

(6, 2).clue: Cushy term for the unregulated donations to political parties from corporate & union treasuries

(1, 3).clue: Alexander Hamilton wanted "the thirteen states bound together in a strict and indissoluble" this

(2, 3).clue: This "Sea of Love" actress had access to the finest of make-up when she married billionaire Ron Perelman

(3, 3).clue: (Hi, I'm Ari Fleischer.)  This TV journalist, commentator & frequent PBS host was Lyndon Johnson's press secretary from 1965 to 1967

(4, 3).clue: According to Homer, this ancient city had numerous gates, including the famous Scaean one

(5, 3).clue: Researchers at Rice University made a molecule-size one of these with a chassis, axles & pivoting suspension

(6, 3).clue: The U.S. has has 4 trade disputes, known as Lumber I, II, III & IV, with Canada over this product

(1, 4).clue: Martin Luther King dreamed of "the table of" this, a crowning quality in "America, The Beautiful"

(2, 4).clue: This singer didn't keep shipping magnate Arne Naess hanging on; she met him in May 1985 & married him in October

(3, 4).clue: Formerly a U.S. Secretary of Energy, he's now the governor of New Mexico

(4, 4).clue: In Norse myth the gate known as Valgrind was the main entrance to this mighty hall

(5, 4).clue: 3-foot long Compsognathus, meaning "pretty jaw", was the smallest of these thought to have existed

(6, 4).clue: A deliberate slight blurring of a filmed image for effect

(1, 5).clue: In December 1940 FDR told the nation, "We must be the great arsenal of" this

(2, 5).clue: In 1895 this crusader married Robert Seaman, but after he died she had to return to reporting to make money

(3, 5).clue: "Bloody Bill Anderson" was the most vicious member of this man's deadly "Raiders" during the U.S. Civil War

(4, 5).clue: It's the historic German gate & landmark seen here

(5, 5).clue: Hamlet alone speaks 1,569 lines; Shakespeare's shortest play at 1,770 lines is this one involving 2 sets of twins

(6, 5).clue: It's the S in the ESA, the association to which video-game sellers like Sony belong

(1, 1).clue: You might howl at this Beat poet's "TV Baby Poems"

(2, 1).clue: Alfred Hitchcock's first American film was this 1940 classic based on a Daphne du Maurier novel

(3, 1).clue: The 8 essential types of these acids cannot be produced by the human body & must be obtained from food

(4, 1).clue: Moscow's coat of arms features St. George slaying one of these with his lance

(5, 1).clue: Henry Waxman,Mary Bono,Jerry Lewis (no, not that one)

(1, 2).clue: While he lived near Pisa, this English poet wrote "Ode to the West Wind" & "To a Skylark"

(2, 2).clue: This animated Disney film that featured a forest fire was the No. 1 box-office draw of 1942

(3, 2).clue: Revive yourself & give the name of this compound of nitrogen & hydrogen that has been used for refrigeration

(4, 2).clue: As you'd expect, this animal appears on the coat of arms of the Ivory Coast

(6, 2).clue: (7)To approve a candidate, or sign the back of a check

(1, 3).clue: Poem containing the line "Perched upon a bust of Pallas just above my chamber door"

(2, 3).clue: This 1940 "Story" starring Cary Grant & Katharine Hepburn was remade as the musical "High Society" in 1956

(3, 3).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew reports from Duke University in Durham, NC.)  Vaulters can use hollow poles to save weight because this center line of a bent pole is neutral, taking little or no stress

(4, 3).clue: This animal is on the Lopez family coat of arms, probably because of the name Lopez comes from the Latin for it

(1, 4).clue: This Robert Frost poem begins "Two roads diverged in a yellow wood"

(2, 4).clue: Claire Trevor won a 1948 Oscar for her role as a gangster's girlfriend in this Bogart flick set on an island

(3, 4).clue: Either dominant or recessive, they can be different forms of the same gene

(4, 4).clue: Wearing a gold collar & chain in the U.K.'s coat of arms, this mythical beast represents Scotland

(6, 4).clue: (9)To make up a story, or to make by art or skill & labor

(1, 5).clue: It's the personal 3-word title of the longest poem in Walt Whitman's "Leaves of Grass"

(2, 5).clue: Marine Ira Hayes, who helped raise the American flag on Mount Suribachi, had a cameo in this 1949 John Wayne film

(3, 5).clue: Probably the most common & best known carnivore of the late Jurassic period, it had a 3-foot-long skull

(4, 5).clue: One of Elizabeth II's coronation "Queen's Beasts" was a female one of these half-lion, half-eagle creatures

(0, 0).clue: Chap. 1: "Until one morning in mid-November of 1959, few Americans--in fact, few Kansans--had ever heard of Holcomb"
